On Bridging Generic and Personalized
Federated Learning for Image Classification

Hong-You Chen
The Ohio State University, USA
&Wei-Lun Chao
The Ohio State University, USA
Abstract

Federated learning is promising for its capability to collaboratively train models with multiple clients without accessing their data, but vulnerable when clientsâ€™ data distributions diverge from each other. This divergence further leads to a dilemma: â€œShould we prioritize the learned modelâ€™s generic performance (for future use at the server) or its personalized performance (for each client)?â€ These two, seemingly competing goals have divided the community to focus on one or the other, yet in this paper we show that it is possible to approach both at the same time. Concretely, we propose a novel federated learning framework that explicitly decouples a modelâ€™s dual duties with two prediction tasks. On the one hand, we introduce a family of losses that are robust to non-identical class distributions, enabling clients to train a generic predictor with a consistent objective across them. On the other hand, we formulate the personalized predictor as a lightweight adaptive module that is learned to minimize each clientâ€™s empirical risk on top of the generic predictor. With this two-loss, two-predictor framework which we name Federated Robust Decoupling (Fed-RoD), the learned model can simultaneously achieve state-of-the-art generic and personalized performance, essentially bridging the two tasks.

1 Introduction

Large-scale data are the driving forces for modern machine learning but come with the risk of data privacy. In applications like health care, data are required to be kept separate to enforce ownership and protection, hindering the collective wisdom (of data) for training strong models. Federated learning (FL), which aims to train a model with multiple data sources (i.e., clients) while keeping their data decentralized, has emerged as a popular paradigm to resolve these concernsÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019).

The standard setup of FL seeks to train a single â€œglobalâ€ model that can perform well on generic data distributions (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019), e.g., the union of clientsâ€™ data. As clientsâ€™ data are kept separate, mainstream algorithms like FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) take a multi-round approach shown in FigureÂ 1. Within each round, the server first broadcasts the â€œglobalâ€ model to the clients, who then independently update the model locally using their own (often limited) data. The server then aggregates the â€œlocalâ€ models back into the â€œglobalâ€ model and proceeds to the next round. This pipeline is shown promising if clientsâ€™ data are IID (i.e., with similar data and label distributions)Â (Zhou & Cong, 2017, Stich, 2019), which is, however, hard to meet in reality and thus results in a drastic performance dropÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b, Zhao etÂ al., 2018). Instead of sticking to a single â€œglobalâ€ model that features the generic performance, another setup of FL seeks to construct a â€œpersonalizedâ€ model for each client to acknowledge the heterogeneity among clients (Smith etÂ al., 2017, Dinh etÂ al., 2020, Hanzely etÂ al., 2020). This latter setup (usually called personalized FL) is shown to outperform the former (which we name generic FL) regarding the test accuracy of each client alone.

So far, these two seemingly contrasting FL setups are developed independently. In this paper, we however found that they can be approached simultaneously by generic FL algorithms like FedAvg.

Concretely, algorithms designed for generic FL (G-FL) often discard the local models {ğ’˜m}subscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\{\bm{w}_{m}\} after training (see FigureÂ 1). As a result, when they are evaluated in a personalized setting (P-FL), it is the global model ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}} being testedÂ (Fallah etÂ al., 2020, Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019, Liang etÂ al., 2020, Zhang etÂ al., 2021, Dinh etÂ al., 2020, Smith etÂ al., 2017, Li etÂ al., 2021a). Here, we found that if we instead keep {ğ’˜m}subscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\{\bm{w}_{m}\} and evaluate them in P-FL, they outperform nearly all the existing P-FL algorithms. In other words, personalized models seem to come for free from the local training step of generic FL.

At first glance, this may not be totally surprising: local training in G-FL algorithms is driven by the clientâ€™s empirical risk, which is what a personalized model strives to optimize111However, when G-FL algorithms are tested on the P-FL setup, the literature does not use their local models.. What really surprises us is that even without an explicit regularization term imposed by most P-FL algorithms (Smith etÂ al., 2017, Dinh etÂ al., 2020), the local models of G-FL algorithms can achieve better generalization performance. We conduct a detailed analysis and argue that global aggregation â€” taking average over model weights â€” indeed acts like a regularizer for local models. Moreover, applying advanced G-FL algorithmsÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021) to improve the G-FL accuracy seems to not hurt the â€œlocalâ€ modelsâ€™ P-FL accuracy.

Building upon these observations, we dig deeper into generic FL. Specifically for classification, the non-IID clients can result from non-identical class distributions or non-identical class-conditional data distributions. One way to mitigate their influences is to make the local training objectives more aligned among clients. While this can hardly be achieved for the latter case without knowing clientsâ€™ data, we can do so for the former case by setting a consistent goal among clients â€” the learned local models should classify every class well, even if clientsâ€™ data have different class distributions. We realize this by viewing each clientâ€™s local training as an independent class-imbalanced problemÂ (Cui etÂ al., 2019, He & Garcia, 2009) and applying objective functions dedicated to it (Cao etÂ al., 2019, Ren etÂ al., 2020). As will be shown in sectionÂ 5, these class-balanced objectives lead to much consistent local training among clients, making the resulting â€œglobalâ€ model more robust to non-IID conditions.

The use of class-balanced objectives, nevertheless, degrades the local modelsâ€™ P-FL performance. This is because the local models are no longer learned to optimize clientsâ€™ empirical risks.

To address this issue, we propose a unifying framework for G-FL and P-FL which explicitly decouples a local modelâ€™s dual duties: serving as the personalized model and the ingredient of the global model. Concretely, we follow the FedAvg pipeline and train the local model with the class-balanced loss, but on top of the feature extractor, we introduce a lightweight personalized predictor and train it with clientâ€™s empirical risk (see FigureÂ 2). With this two-loss, two-predictor framework which we name Federated Robust Decoupling (Fed-RoD), the resulting global model can be more robust to non-identical class distributions; the personalized predictor can lead to decent P-FL accuracy due to the implicit regularization and the empirical loss. Specifically for the personalized predictor, we propose to explicitly parameterize it with clientsâ€™ class distributions via a hypernetwork (Ha etÂ al., 2017). That is, we learn a shared meta-model that outputs personalized predictors for clients given their class distributions. This not only enables zero-shot model adaptation to new clients (without their data but class distributions), but also provides a better initialization to fine-tune the models given new clientsâ€™ data.

We validate Fed-RoD on multiple datasets under various non-IID settings. Fed-RoD consistently outperforms existing generic and personalized FL algorithms in both setups. Moreover, Fed-RoD is compatible with and can further improve advanced generic FL algorithms like FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021) whenever non-identical class distributions occur. Our contributions are three-folded:

  • â€¢

    Unlike most of the previous works that focus on either generic FL or personalized FL, we propose Fed-RoD to excel on both at the same time. We validate Fed-RoD with extensive experiments.

  • â€¢

    We show that strong personalized models emerge from the local training step of generic FL algorithms, due to implicit regularization. We further show that class-balanced objectives are effective for improving the generic FL performance when clients have different class distributions.

  • â€¢

    Fed-RoD enables zero-shot adaptation and much effective fine-tuning for new clients.

2 Related Work (A detailed version is in AppendixÂ A)

Generic federated learning. FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is the standard algorithm, and many works are proposed to improve it, either in the global aggregation stepÂ (Yurochkin etÂ al., 2019, Wang etÂ al., 2020a, Lin etÂ al., 2020, Chen & Chao, 2021, Hsu etÂ al., 2019, Reddi etÂ al., 2021) or local training stepÂ (Malinovskiy etÂ al., 2020, Yuan & Ma, 2020, Zhao etÂ al., 2018, Wang etÂ al., 2020b). For example, to reduce local modelsâ€™ drifts from the global model, FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020a) and FedDyn (Acar etÂ al., 2021) employed regularization toward the global model; SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020a) leveraged control variates to correct local gradients. We also aim to reduce local modelsâ€™ drifts but via a different way. We apply objective functions in class-imbalanced learning (He & Garcia, 2009), which are designed to be robust to class distribution changes. The closest to ours is (Hsu etÂ al., 2020), which used a traditional class-imbalanced treatment named re-weighting. We show that more advanced techniques can be applied to further improve the performance, especially under extreme non-IID conditions where re-weighting is ineffective.

Personalized federated learning. Many approaches for personalized FL (Kulkarni etÂ al., 2020) are based on multi-task learning (MTL)Â (Zhang & Yang, 2017, Ruder, 2017). For instance, Smith etÂ al. (2017) encouraged related clients to learn similar models; Li etÂ al. (2021a), Dinh etÂ al. (2020), Hanzely etÂ al. (2020) regularized local models with a learnable global model. Our approach is inspired by MTL as well but has notable differences. First, we found that global aggregation in generic FL already serves as a strong regularizer. Second, instead of learning for each client a feature extractor (Bui etÂ al., 2019, Liang etÂ al., 2020) or an entire model, Fed-RoD shares a single feature extractor among clients, inspired by Zhang etÂ al. (2014), Caruana (1997). This reduces the total parameters to be learned and improves generalization. Compared to (Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019, Collins etÂ al., 2021) which also learned a shared feature extractor, Fed-RoD simultaneously excels in both FL setups.

Instead of designing specific algorithms for personalized FL, Yu etÂ al. (2020), Wang etÂ al. (2019), Cheng etÂ al. (2021) showed that performing post-processing (e.g., fine-tuning) to a generic FL model (e.g., ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}} in FedAvg) leads to promising personalized accuracy. We further showed that, the local models {ğ’˜m}subscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\{\bm{w}_{m}\} learned in FedAvg and other generic FL algorithms are strong personalized models.

We note that, while many personalized FL algorithms also produce a global model, it is mainly used to regularize or construct personalized models but not for evaluation in the generic setup. In contrast, we learn models to excel in both setups via a single framework without sacrificing either of them.

A recent work pFedHNÂ (Shamsian etÂ al., 2021) also applies hypernetworksÂ (Ha etÂ al., 2017) but in a very different way from Fed-RoD. pFedHN learns a hypernetwork at the server to aggregate clientsâ€™ updates and produce entire models for them for the next round. In contrast, we learn the hypernetwork locally to construct the personalized predictors, not the entire models, for fast adaptation to clients.

3 Personalized Models Emerge from Generic Federated Learning

In this section, we show that personalized FL (P-FL) models emerge from the training process of generic FL (G-FL) algorithms. To begin with, we review representative G-FL and P-FL algorithms.

Federated averaging (FedAvg). As clientsâ€™ data are separate, EquationÂ 1 cannot be solved directly. A standard way to relax it is FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), which iterates between two steps, local training and global aggregation, for multiple rounds of communication

The global aggregation is by taking element-wise average over model weights. Terminology.

Let us clarify the concepts of â€œglobalâ€ vs. â€œlocalâ€ models, and â€œgenericâ€ vs. â€œpersonalizedâ€ models. The former corresponds to the training phase: local models are the ones after every round of local training, which are then aggregated into the global model at the server (EquationÂ 2). The latter corresponds to the testing phase: the generic model is used at the server for generic future test data, while personalized models are specifically used for each clientâ€™s test data.

3.2 Local models of generic FL algorithms are strong personalized models

Building upon the aforementioned concepts, we investigate the literature and found that when generic FL algorithms are evaluated in the P-FL setup, it is their global models being tested. In contrast, when personalized FL algorithms are applied, it is their local models (e.g., EquationÂ 4) being tested. This discrepancy motivates us to instead evaluate generic FL algorithms using their local models.

FigureÂ 1 summarizes the results (seeÂ sectionÂ 5 for details). Using local models of FedAvg (i.e., EquationÂ 2) notably outperforms using its global model in the P-FL setup. At first glance, this may not be surprising, as local training in FedAvg is driven by clientsâ€™ empirical risks. What really surprises us, as will be seen in sectionÂ 5, is that FedAvgâ€™s local models outperform most of the existing personalized FL algorithms, even if no explicit regularization is imposed in EquationÂ 2.

3.3 Initialization with weight average is a strong regularizer

To gain a further understanding, we plot FedAvg local modelsâ€™ accuracy on clientsâ€™ training and test data. We do so also for a state-of-the-art personalized FL algorithm DittoÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021a), whose local training step for producing personalized models is similar to EquationÂ 4. As shown in FigureÂ 3, FedAvg has a lower training but higher test accuracy, implying that FedAvgâ€™s local training is more regularized than EquationÂ 4.

We attribute this effect to the initialization in EquationÂ 2. Specifically, by initializing ğ’˜ğ’˜\bm{w} with ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}}, we essentially impose an L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} regularizer Î»2â€‹â€–ğ’˜âˆ’ğ’˜Â¯â€–22ğœ†2superscriptsubscriptnormğ’˜Â¯ğ’˜22\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\bm{w}-\bar{\bm{w}}\|_{2}^{2} with Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty at the beginning of each round of local training, followed by resetting Î»ğœ†\lambda to be 00. We found that this implicit regularization leads to a smaller value of â€–ğ’˜âˆ’ğ’˜Â¯â€–22superscriptsubscriptnormğ’˜Â¯ğ’˜22\|\bm{w}-\bar{\bm{w}}\|_{2}^{2} at the end of each local training round, compared to EquationÂ 4. Due to the page limit, we leave additional analyses in the appendix. We note that, advanced generic FL algorithms like SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b) and FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021) still apply this initialization and learn with the empirical risk during local training. Thus, their local models are strong personalized models as well.

4 Federated Robust Decoupling (Fed-RoD)

The fact that personalized models emerge from generic FL algorithms motivate us to focus more on how to improve the latter, especially when clients have non-IID data distributions.

4.1 Improving generic FL with Balanced Risk Minimization (BRM)

We first analyze what factors may lead to non-IID conditions. Suppose the data instance (ğ’™,y)ğ’™ğ‘¦({\bm{x}},y) of client mğ‘šm is sampled from a client-specific joint distribution ğ’«mâ€‹(ğ’™,y)=ğ’«mâ€‹(ğ’™|y)â€‹ğ’«mâ€‹(y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šğ’™ğ‘¦subscriptğ’«ğ‘šconditionalğ’™ğ‘¦subscriptğ’«ğ‘šğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}({\bm{x}},y)=\mathcal{P}_{m}({\bm{x}}|y)\mathcal{P}_{m}(y), the non-IID distributions among clients can result from non-identical class distributions ğ’«mâ€‹(ğ’™|y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šconditionalğ’™ğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}({\bm{x}}|y), non-identical class-conditional data distributions ğ’«mâ€‹(y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}(y), or both. All these cases can make â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}) deviate from â„’â€‹(ğ’˜)â„’ğ’˜\mathcal{L}(\bm{w}) in EquationÂ 1, which is the main cause of degradation in generic FLÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b; a).

One way to mitigate the influence of non-IID data is to make â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}) align with each other. This can be challenging to achieve if clients have different ğ’«mâ€‹(ğ’™|y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šconditionalğ’™ğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}({\bm{x}}|y): without knowing clientsâ€™ data222Clients having different ğ’«mâ€‹(ğ’™|y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šconditionalğ’™ğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}({\bm{x}}|y) is related to domain adaptation (Gong etÂ al., 2012) and generalizationÂ (Muandet etÂ al., 2013), which require knowing the distributions of all/some clients for algorithm design., it is hard to design such an aligned â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}). However, when clients have different ğ’«mâ€‹(y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}(y)333This is indeed the main cause of non-IID data distributions in the literature of FL (Hsu etÂ al., 2019; 2020)., i.e., different and hence imbalanced class distributions, we can indeed design a consistent local training objective by setting a shared goal for the clients â€” the learned local models should classify all the classes well. It is worth noting that setting such a goal does not require every client to know othersâ€™ data.

Learning a classifier to perform well on all classes irrespective of the training class distribution is the main focus of class-imbalanced learningÂ (Johnson & Khoshgoftaar, 2019, He & Garcia, 2009, Japkowicz, 2000). We therefore propose to treat each clientâ€™s local training as a class-imbalanced learning problem and leverage techniques developed in this sub-field. Re-weighting and re-sampling (Buda etÂ al., 2018) are the most fundamental techniques. Denote by Nm,csubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘N_{m,c} the number of training instances of class cğ‘c for client mğ‘šm, these techniques adjust â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}) in EquationÂ 1 into

â„’mBâ€‹Râ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆâˆ‘iqyiâ€‹â„“â€‹(ğ’™i,yi;ğ’˜),Â whereÂ â€‹qyiâ€‹Â is usually set asÂ â€‹1Nm,yiâ€‹Â orÂ â€‹1Nm,yi.proportional-tosuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…ğ’˜subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–â„“subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ’˜Â whereÂ subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–Â is usually set asÂ 1subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–Â orÂ 1subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}}(\bm{w})\propto\sum_{i}{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}q_{y_{i}}}\ell({\bm{x}}_{i},y_{i};\bm{w}),\hskip 10.0pt\text{ where }q_{y_{i}}\text{ is usually set as }\frac{1}{N_{m,y_{i}}}\text{ or }\frac{1}{\sqrt{N_{m,y_{i}}}}. Namely, they mitigate the influence of ğ’«mâ€‹(y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}(y) by turning the empirical risk â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m} into a balanced risk â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}}, such that every client solves a more consistent objective that is robust to the class distributions. Recently, many class-imbalanced works proposed to replace the instance loss â„“â„“\ell (e.g., cross entropy) with a class-balanced loss (Ren etÂ al., 2020, Cao etÂ al., 2019, Ye etÂ al., 2020, Khan etÂ al., 2017, Kang etÂ al., 2020), showing more promising results than re-weighting or re-sampling. We can also define â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}} using these losses, e.g., the balanced softmax (BSM) loss (Ren etÂ al., 2020)

â„’mBâ€‹Râ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆâˆ‘iâ„“BSMâ€‹(ğ’™i,yi;ğ’˜),Â whereÂ â€‹â„“BSMâ€‹(ğ’™,y;ğ’˜)=âˆ’logâ¡Nm,yÎ³â€‹expâ¡(gyâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’˜))âˆ‘câˆˆâ„‚Nm,cÎ³â€‹expâ¡(gcâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’˜)).formulae-sequenceproportional-tosuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…ğ’˜subscriptğ‘–superscriptâ„“BSMsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ’˜Â whereÂ superscriptâ„“BSMğ’™ğ‘¦ğ’˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘šğ‘¦subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¦ğ’™ğ’˜subscriptğ‘â„‚subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ›¾ğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğ’™ğ’˜\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}}(\bm{w})\propto\sum_{i}\ell^{\text{BSM}}({\bm{x}}_{i},y_{i};\bm{w}),\hskip 2.5pt\text{ where }\hskip 2.5pt\ell^{\text{BSM}}({\bm{x}},y;\bm{w})=-\log\frac{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}N^{\gamma}_{m,y}}\exp(g_{y}({\bm{x}};\bm{w}))}{\sum_{c\in\mathbb{C}}{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}N^{\gamma}_{m,c}}\exp(g_{c}({\bm{x}};\bm{w}))}. (6)

Here, gcâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’˜)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğ’™ğ’˜g_{c}({\bm{x}};\bm{w}) is the logit for class cğ‘c, â„‚â„‚\mathbb{C} is the label space, and Î³ğ›¾\gamma is a hyper-parameter. The BSM loss is an unbiased extension of softmax to accommodate the class distribution shift between training and testing. It encourages a minor-class instance to claim a larger logit gyâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’˜)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¦ğ’™ğ’˜g_{y}({\bm{x}};\bm{w}) in training to overcome feature deviation (Ye etÂ al., 2020) in testing. We list other class-balanced losses in the appendix.

We take advantage of these existing efforts by replacing the empirical risk â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m} in EquationÂ 2 with a balanced risk â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}}, which either takes the form of EquationÂ 5 or applies a class-balanced loss (e.g., EquationÂ 6), or both. We note that, a variant of EquationÂ 5 has been used in (Hsu etÂ al., 2020). However, our experiments show that it is less effective than class-balanced losses in extreme non-IID cases. Interestingly, we found that â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}} can easily be incorporated into advanced FL algorithms like FedDyn (Acar etÂ al., 2021), because these algorithms are agnostic to the local objectives being used.

4.2 Local training and local model decoupling with ERM and BRM

The use of balanced risk â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}} in local training notably improves the resulting global model ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}}â€™s generic performance, as will be seen in sectionÂ 5. Nevertheless, it inevitably hurts the local model ğ’˜msubscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m}â€™s personalized performance, since it is no longer optimized towards clientâ€™s empirical risk â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m}.

To address these contrasting pursuits of generic and personalized FL, we propose a unifying FL framework named Federated Robust Decoupling (Fed-RoD), which decouples the dual duties of local models by learning two predictors on top of a shared feature extractor: one trained with empirical risk minimization (ERM) for personalized FL (P-FL) and the other with balanced risk minimization (BRM) for generic FL (G-FL). FigureÂ 4 (c-d) illustrates the model and local training objective of Fed-RoD. The overall training process of Fed-RoD follows FedAvg, iterating between local training and global aggregation. As mentioned in subsectionÂ 4.1, other generic FL algorithmsÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021, Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b, Li etÂ al., 2020a) can easily be applied to the BRM branch to further improve the generic performance. Without loss of generality, we focus on the basic version built upon FedAvg. We start with the model in FigureÂ 4 (c).

Notations.

We denote by fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğœ½)ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½f({\bm{x}};\bm{\theta}) the shared feature extractor parameterized by ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}, whose output is ğ’›ğ’›{\bm{z}}. We denote by hGâ€‹(ğ’›;ğ)superscriptâ„ğºğ’›ğh^{G}({\bm{z}};\bm{\psi}) and hPâ€‹(ğ’›;Ï•m)superscriptâ„ğ‘ƒğ’›subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šh^{P}({\bm{z}};\bm{\phi}_{m}) the generic and personalized prediction heads parameterized by ğğ\bm{\psi} and Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m}, respectively; both are fully-connected (FC) layers. In short, our generic model is parameterized by {ğœ½,ğ}ğœ½ğ\{\bm{\theta},\bm{\psi}\}; our personalized model for client mğ‘šm is parameterized by {ğœ½,ğ,Ï•m}ğœ½ğsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\{\bm{\theta},\bm{\psi},\bm{\phi}_{m}\}.

Predictions.

For generic prediction, we perform ğ’›=fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğœ½)ğ’›ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½{\bm{z}}=f({\bm{x}};\bm{\theta}), followed by y^G=hGâ€‹(ğ’›;ğ)subscript^ğ‘¦ğºsuperscriptâ„ğºğ’›ğ\hat{y}_{G}=h^{G}({\bm{z}};\bm{\psi}). For personalized prediction, we perform fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğœ½)ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½f({\bm{x}};\bm{\theta}), followed by y^P=hGâ€‹(ğ’›;ğ)+hPâ€‹(ğ’›;Ï•m)subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘ƒsuperscriptâ„ğºğ’›ğsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ƒğ’›subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\hat{y}_{P}=h^{G}({\bm{z}};\bm{\psi})+h^{P}({\bm{z}};\bm{\phi}_{m}). That is, hPsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ƒh^{P} is an add-on to hGsuperscriptâ„ğºh^{G}, providing personalized information that is not captured by the generic head.

The overall objective.

Fed-RoD learns the generic model with the balanced risk â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}} and the personalized predictor with the empirical risk â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m}. That is, different from EquationÂ 1, Fed-RoD aims to solve the following two optimization problems simultaneously

We note that, â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m} is only used to learn the personalized head parameterized by Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m}.

4.3 Adaptive personalized predictors via hypernetworks

In subsectionÂ 4.2, the parameter Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} of the personalized predictor is learned independently for each client and never shared across clients. In other words, for a new client not involved in the training phase, Fed-RoD can only offer the global model for generic prediction. In this subsection, we investigate learning a shared personalized predictor that can adapt to new clients. Concretely, we propose to learn a meta-model which can generate Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} for a client given the clientâ€™s class distribution. We denote by HPâ€‹(ğ’‚m;ğ‚)superscriptğ»ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’‚ğ‘šğ‚H^{P}(\bm{a}_{m};\bm{\nu}) the meta-model parameterized by ğ‚ğ‚\bm{\nu}, whose output is Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m}. Here, ğ’‚mâˆˆâ„|â„‚|subscriptğ’‚ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„â„‚\bm{a}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathbb{C}|} is the |â„‚|â„‚|\mathbb{C}|-dimensional vector that records the class distribution of client mğ‘šm; i.e., the cğ‘c-th dimension amâ€‹[c]=Nm,câˆ‘câ€²Nm,câ€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘â€²a_{m}[c]=\frac{N_{m,c}}{\sum_{c^{\prime}}N_{m,c^{\prime}}}. Accordingly, the local training step of Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} in EquationÂ 9 is replaced by

Local:Â â€‹ğ‚mâ‹†=argâ€‹minğ‚â¡â„’mâ€‹({ğœ½,ğ,ğ‚}),Â initialized withÂ â€‹ğ‚Â¯;Global:Â â€‹ğ‚Â¯â†âˆ‘m=1M|ğ’Ÿm||ğ’Ÿ|â€‹ğ‚mâ‹†.formulae-sequenceLocal:Â subscriptsuperscriptğ‚â‹†ğ‘šsubscriptargminğ‚subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğœ½ğğ‚Â initialized withÂ Â¯ğ‚â†Global:Â Â¯ğ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‚ğ‘šâ‹†\displaystyle\textbf{Local: }\hskip 4.0pt\bm{\nu}^{\star}_{m}=\operatorname{arg\,min}_{\bm{\nu}}\mathcal{L}_{m}(\{\bm{\theta},\bm{\psi},\bm{\nu}\}),\text{ initialized with }\bar{\bm{\nu}};\hskip 8.0pt\textbf{Global: }\hskip 4.0pt\bar{\bm{\nu}}\leftarrow\sum_{m=1}^{M}\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{m}|}{|\mathcal{D}|}{\bm{\nu}_{m}^{\star}}. We implement HPsuperscriptğ»ğ‘ƒH^{P} by a lightweight hypernetwork (Ha etÂ al., 2017) with two fully-connected layers. With the learned ğ‚Â¯Â¯ğ‚\bar{\bm{\nu}}, the meta-model HPsuperscriptğ»ğ‘ƒH^{P} can locally generate Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} based on ğ’‚msubscriptğ’‚ğ‘š\bm{a}_{m}, making it adaptive to new clients simply by class distributions. The parameter Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} can be further updated using clientsâ€™ data. We name this version Fed-RoD (hyper); the previous one, Fed-RoD (linear). Please see FigureÂ 4 (c-d) for an illustration. We include more details in the appendix.

5 Experiment (More Details and Results in The Appendix)

Datasets, models, and settings. We use CIFAR-10/100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) and Fashion-MNIST (FMNIST)Â (Xiao etÂ al., 2017). We also include a realistic EMNISTÂ (Cohen etÂ al., 2017) dataset, which collects hand-written letters of thousands of writers. To simulate the non-IID data distributions on CIFAR and FMNIST, we follow Hsu etÂ al. (2019) to create a heterogeneous partition for Mğ‘€M clients: an Mğ‘€M-dimensional vector ğ’’csubscriptğ’’ğ‘\bm{q}_{c} is drawn from Dirâ€‹(Î±)Dirğ›¼\text{Dir}(\alpha) for class cğ‘c, and we assign data of class cğ‘c to client mğ‘šm proportionally to ğ’’câ€‹[m]subscriptğ’’ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘š\bm{q}_{c}[m]. The resulting clients have different numbers of total images and different class distributions. With Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1, most of the training examples of one class are likely assigned to a small portion of clients. Similar toÂ Lin etÂ al. (2020), we use M=100ğ‘€100M=100 clients for FMNIST and M=20ğ‘€20M=20 for CIFAR-10/100, and sample 20%/40%percent20percent4020\%/40\% clients at every round, respectively. For EMNIST, we use the digit images, followÂ Caldas etÂ al. (2018) to construct 2,18521852,185 clients (each is a writer), and sample 5%percent55\% clients at every round. We use a ConvNetÂ (LeCun etÂ al., 1998) similar to (McMahan etÂ al., 2017, Acar etÂ al., 2021). It contains 333 convolutional layers and 222 fully-connected layers. We train every FL algorithm for 100100100 rounds, with 555 local epochs in each round.

We report the mean accuracy of five times of experiments with different random seeds. We evaluate the generic performance (G-FL) using the generic model (GM) on the standard generic test set. For FMNIST and CIFAR-10/100, we evaluate the personalized performance (P-FL) using personalized models (PM) on the same set, but re-weight the accuracy according to clientsâ€™ class distributions Pmâ€‹(y)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šğ‘¦P_{m}(y) and average the weighted accuracy across Mğ‘€M clients as 1Mâ€‹âˆ‘mâˆ‘iğ’«mâ€‹(yi)â€‹1â€‹(yi=y^i)âˆ‘iğ’«mâ€‹(yi)1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’«ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’«ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m}\frac{\sum_{i}\mathcal{P}_{m}(y_{i})\textbf{1}(y_{i}=\hat{y}_{i})}{\sum_{i}\mathcal{P}_{m}(y_{i})}. Here, iğ‘–i is the instance index. This evaluation is more robust (essentially as the expectation) than assigning each client a specific test set. For EMNIST, each client has its own test set with the same writing style.

Our variants. We mainly use EquationÂ 6 with Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 as the â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{BR}} and report the Fed-RoD (hyper) version (cf. subsectionÂ 4.3). TableÂ 4 provides the ablation study.

Baselines. For G-FL methods including FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020a), SCAFFOLD (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b), and FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021), we use their global models ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}} for G-FL evaluation; their local models (i.e., ğ’˜msubscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m} in FigureÂ 1) for P-FL evaluation. For P-FL methods, to evaluate their G-FL performance, we use the available global models in pFedMeÂ (Dinh etÂ al., 2020) and DittoÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021a) or average the final personalized models for MTLÂ (Smith etÂ al., 2017), FedPerÂ (Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019), LG-FedAvgÂ (Liang etÂ al., 2020), FedFOMOÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021), and FedRepÂ (Collins etÂ al., 2021).

To illustrate the difference between applying GMs and PMs in a P-FL setting, we also evaluate the P-FL performance using GMs, which is how FedAvg has been applied to P-FL in literature.

5.1 Results

Fed-RoD bridges G-FL and P-FL and consistently outperforms all generic and personalized FL methods. TableÂ 1 summarizes the results. In terms of G-FL accuracy, advanced local training (i.e., SCAFFOLD, FedProx, and FedDyn) outperforms FedAvg and personalized methods, and our Fed-RoD can have further gains by using balanced risk minimization (BRM). We also investigate combining Fed-RoD and FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021), using the latter to optimize the generic model with BRM, which outperforms either ingredient in many cases. We report the G-FL accuracy of personalized FL algorithms mainly to investigate if they have similar properties like FedAvg: an algorithm designed for one setup can also construct models for the other setup.

In terms of P-FL accuracy, by using PMs most methods outperform the baseline of local training with individual clientâ€™s data without communication (i.e., local only), justifying the benefits of federated collaboration444PMs of â€œlocal onlyâ€ could outperform the GM of FedAvg on the P-FL accuracy, especially when the non-IID condition becomes severe (e.g., Dir (0.1)): it is hard to train a single GM to perform well in P-FL.. For generic FL methods, using PMs (i.e., local models {ğ’˜m}subscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\{\bm{w}_{m}\}) clearly outperforms using GMs (i.e., ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}}), which supports our claims and observations in FigureÂ 1 and subsectionÂ 3.2. It is worth noting that the local models from generic FL methods are highly competitive to or even outperform personalized models produced by personalized FL methods. This provides generic FL methods with an add-on functionality to output personalized models by keeping the checkpoints on clients after local training. Our Fed-RoD achieves the highest P-FL accuracy and we attribute this to (a) the shared feature extractor learned with the balanced risk and re-initialized every round to benefit from implicit regularization; (b) the personalized head learned with clientsâ€™ empirical risks.

BRM effectively reduces the variance of G-FL accuracy and local gradients. To understand why Fed-RoD improves G-FL, we visualize the global model ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}}â€™s and each local model ğ’˜msubscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m}â€™s G-FL accuracy on CIFAR-10 (Dir(0.3)), inÂ FigureÂ 5 (upper). Fed-RoD not only learns a better global model for G-FL, but also has a smaller variance of accuracy across the local modelsâ€™ generic heads (as their objectives are more aligned). We also show how ğ’˜msubscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m} deviates from ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}} after local training in FigureÂ 5 (lower). Fed-RoD has a smaller variance. This coincides with the study inÂ (Kong etÂ al., 2021): lower variances of the local gradients could imply better generic performance.

Fed-RoD benefits from decoupling.

We compare several variants of Fed-RoD (cf.Â FigureÂ 4), with one head (reduced to FedAvg) or different networks (linear/hyper). We evaluate on CIFAR-10 (Dir(0.3)). As shown inÂ TableÂ 4, FedAvg with BRM significantly improves G-FL but degrades in P-FL. Fed-RoD remedies this by training a decoupled personalized head. We note that, Fed-RoD does not merely fine-tune the global model with clientsâ€™ data (cf. subsectionÂ 4.2). We also compare different balanced losses inÂ TableÂ 4: advanced losses outperforms importance re-weightingÂ (Hsu etÂ al., 2020).

Fed-RoD (hyper) benefits future clients.

To validate the generalizability to new clients, we build on the Dir(0.3) non-IID setting for FMNIST and CIFAR-10/100, but split the training data into 100100100 clients (505050 are in training; 505050 are new). We train on the 505050 training clients for 100100100 rounds (sampling 202020 of them every round). We then evaluate on the 50 new clients individually, either using the global model directly or fine-tuning it with clientsâ€™ data for several steps.Â TableÂ 4 and FigureÂ 6 shows the averaged accuracy on new clients. Without fine-tuning, Fed-RoD (hyper) can already generate personalized models, and outperforms others methods stably with fine-tuning.

More results and analyses in the Appendix.

The Appendix includes studies with class-imbalanced global distributions and we show that Fed-RoD still performs well. BRM can be further improved with meta-learned hyper-parameters. We validate that re-initializing the local models by the global model at every round (i.e., EquationÂ 2) does lead to a much smaller regularization loss than EquationÂ 4 to support our claim inÂ subsectionÂ 3.3. More comprehensive results regarding more clients, deeper backbones, compatibility with other methods, robustness against adversaries, etc, are also provided.

6 Conclusion

Most of the existing work in federated learning (FL) has been dedicated to either learning a better generic model or personalized models. We show that these two contrasting goals can be achieved simultaneously via a novel two-loss, two-predictor FL framework Fed-RoD. Concretely, we show that strong personalized models emerge from the local training of generic FL algorithms, due to implicit regularization; imposing class-balanced objectives further improves the generic FL accuracy when clients have non-IID distributions. Fed-RoD seamlessly incorporates these two observations to excel in both FL settings, and further enables fast adaptation to new clients via an adaptive module.

Appendix A Comparison to Related Work

A.1 Follow-up works of FedAvg

Several recent works (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b; a, Zhao etÂ al., 2018) have shown that, with multiple steps of local SGD updates, the local model ğ’˜msubscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m} would drift away from each other, leading to a degenerated global model ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}} that deviates from the solution of EquationÂ 1 of the main text.

One way to mitigate this is to modify the local training objective (cf. EquationÂ 2 of the main text). For instance, FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020a) introduced a regularizer with respect to ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}},

minğ’˜â¡â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)+Î»2â€‹â€–ğ’˜âˆ’ğ’˜Â¯â€–2.subscriptğ’˜subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜ğœ†2superscriptnormğ’˜Â¯ğ’˜2\displaystyle\min_{\bm{w}}\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\bm{w}-\bar{\bm{w}}\|^{2}.

FedDyn (Acar etÂ al., 2021) further added a dynamic term based on the local model of the previous round ğ’˜mâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’˜â€²ğ‘š\bm{w}^{\prime}_{m},

minğ’˜â¡â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)+âŸ¨âˆ‡â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜mâ€²),ğ’˜âŸ©+Î»2â€‹â€–ğ’˜âˆ’ğ’˜Â¯â€–2.subscriptğ’˜subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜âˆ‡subscriptâ„’ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ’˜â€²ğ‘šğ’˜ğœ†2superscriptnormğ’˜Â¯ğ’˜2\displaystyle\min_{\bm{w}}\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w})+\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}^{\prime}_{m}),\bm{w}\rangle+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\bm{w}-\bar{\bm{w}}\|^{2}.

These regularizers aim to stabilize local training and align the objectives among clients. Some other works did not change the objectives but introduced control variates or momentum to correct the local gradientÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020a; b), or designed a new optimizer more suitable for decentralized learningÂ (Malinovskiy etÂ al., 2020, Yuan & Ma, 2020, Pathak & Wainwright, 2020).

It is worth mentioning, in most of these works, the empirical risk â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}) still plays an important role in driving the local model update. Since â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}) directly reflects the (non-IID) client data distribution, the learned local models are indeed strong candidates for personalized models.

A.2 Generic federated learning

FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is the standard algorithm, which involves multiple rounds of local training and global aggregation. Many works have studied its convergence (Khaled etÂ al., 2020, Haddadpour & Mahdavi, 2019), robustness (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2019), communication (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016, Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2019), especially for non-IID clients (Li etÂ al., 2020b, Zhao etÂ al., 2018, Li etÂ al., 2020a). Many other works proposed to improve FedAvg. In terms of global aggregation, (Yurochkin etÂ al., 2019, Wang etÂ al., 2020a) matched local model weights before averaging. (Lin etÂ al., 2020, He etÂ al., 2020, Zhou etÂ al., 2020, Chen & Chao, 2021) replaced weight average by model ensemble and distillation. (Hsu etÂ al., 2019, Reddi etÂ al., 2021) applied server momentum and adaptive optimization to improve the global model update. In terms of local training, (Malinovskiy etÂ al., 2020, Yuan & Ma, 2020, Pathak & Wainwright, 2020, Liang etÂ al., 2019) improved the optimizer. To reduce local modelsâ€™ drifts from the global model, (Zhao etÂ al., 2018) mixed client and server data in local training; FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020a), FedDANE (Li etÂ al., 2019), and FedDyn (Acar etÂ al., 2021) employed regularization toward the global model; SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020a) Mime (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b) leveraged control varieties and/or server statistics to correct local gradients; (Wang etÂ al., 2020b, Yao etÂ al., 2019) modified the local model update rules. For most of them, the empirical risks on clientsâ€™ data are the major forces to drive local training.

We also aim to reduce local modelsâ€™ drifts but via a different way. We directly bypass the empirical risks that reflect clientsâ€™ data distributions. Instead, we apply objective functions in class-imbalanced learning (He & Garcia, 2009), which are designed to be robust to the change of class distributions. Our approach is different from (Wang etÂ al., 2020c, Yang etÂ al., 2020, Duan etÂ al., 2020), which monitored and resolved class imbalance from the server while we tackled it at the clients. Our approach is also different from agnostic FL (Mohri etÂ al., 2019, Deng etÂ al., 2020b), whose local training is still built on empirical risk minimization. The closest to ours is (Hsu etÂ al., 2020), which used a traditional class-imbalanced treatment, re-weighting, to mitigate non-identical class distributions. We show that more advanced techniques can be applied to further improve the performance, especially under extreme non-IID conditions where re-weighting is less effective. Moreover, our method is compatible with existing efforts like FedDyn (Acar etÂ al., 2021) and SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020a) to boost the generic performance.

A.3 Personalized federated learning

Personalized FL (Kulkarni etÂ al., 2020) learns a customized model for each client. Many approaches are based on multi-task learning (MTL)Â (Zhang & Yang, 2017, Ruder, 2017, Evgeniou & Pontil, 2004; 2007, Jacob etÂ al., 2009, Zhang & Yeung, 2010) â€” leveraging the clientsâ€™ task relatedness to improve model generalizability. For instance, (Smith etÂ al., 2017) encouraged related clients to learn similar models; (Li etÂ al., 2021a, Dinh etÂ al., 2020, Hanzely etÂ al., 2020, Hanzely & RichtÃ¡rik, 2020, Corinzia & Buhmann, 2019, Li & Wang, 2019) regularized local models with a learnable global model, prior, or set of data logits. (Liang etÂ al., 2020, Li etÂ al., 2021b, Bui etÂ al., 2019, Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019) designed the model architecture to have both personalized (usually the feature extractor) and shareable components. (Zhang etÂ al., 2021, Huang etÂ al., 2021) constructed for each client an initialized model or regularizer based on learnable bases. Our approach is inspired by MTL as well but has several notable differences from existing works. First, we found that the global aggregation step in generic FL already serves as a strong regularizer. Second, instead of learning for each client a personalized feature extractor (Bui etÂ al., 2019, Liang etÂ al., 2020) or an entire independent model that can operate alone (Smith etÂ al., 2017, Dinh etÂ al., 2020, Hanzely etÂ al., 2020), Fed-RoD shares a single feature extractor among all clients, inspired by invariant risk minimization (Arjovsky etÂ al., 2019, Ahuja etÂ al., 2020) and domain generalization (Muandet etÂ al., 2013, Ghifary etÂ al., 2015). This reduces the total parameters to be learned and improves modelâ€™s generalizability. Compared to FedPerÂ (Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019) and FedRepÂ (Collins etÂ al., 2021) which also learned a shared feature extractor, Fed-RoD simultaneously outputs a single, strong global model to excel in the generic FL setup.

Some other approaches are based on mixture models. (Peterson etÂ al., 2019, Deng etÂ al., 2020a, Mansour etÂ al., 2020, Agarwal etÂ al., 2020, Zec etÂ al., 2020) (separately) learned global and personalized models and performed a mixture of them for prediction. (Reisser etÂ al., 2021) learned a sets of expert models and used them to construct personalized models. Meta-learning is also applied to learn a good initialized model that can be adapted to each client with a few steps of local trainingÂ (Khodak etÂ al., 2019, Chen etÂ al., 2018, Fallah etÂ al., 2020, Jiang etÂ al., 2019).

Instead of designing specific algorithms for personalized FL, (Yu etÂ al., 2020, Wang etÂ al., 2019) showed that performing post-processing (e.g., fine-tuning) to a generic FL model (e.g., ğ’˜Â¯Â¯ğ’˜\bar{\bm{w}} learned by FedAvg) already leads to promising personalized accuracy. In this work, we further showed that, the local models ğ’˜msubscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m} learned in FedAvg and other generic FL algorithms are indeed strong personalized models.

We note that, while many personalized FL algorithms also produce a global model, it is mainly used to regularize or construct personalized models but not for evaluation in the generic setup. In contrast, we learn models to excel in both the setups via a single framework without sacrificing either of them.

pFedHNÂ (Shamsian etÂ al., 2021) also applies hypernetworksÂ (Ha etÂ al., 2017) but for a very different purpose from Fed-RoD. Specifically, pFedHN learns a hypernetwork at the server to aggregate clientsâ€™ model updates and produce their entire models for the next round. In contrast, we learn the hypernetwork locally to construct the personalized predictors, not the entire models, for fast adaptation to clients.

A.4 Averaging model weights as a regularizer

InÂ subsectionÂ 3.3, we demonstrate that taking the average over model weights indeed acts as a regularizer for local models to improve their individual personalized performance.

In more traditional machine learning, the regularization effects of averaging multiple independently-trained models have been observed in some techniques like baggingÂ (Poggio etÂ al., 2002, Skurichina & Duin, 1998). Indeed, in several recent works of FLÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020, He etÂ al., 2020, Zhou etÂ al., 2020, Chen & Chao, 2021), the authors replaced weight average by bagging/model ensemble to improve the generic performance on the global test set. That is, they found that performing the model ensemble over clientsâ€™ models can yield more robust predictions on the global test set than the global model, which is generated by averaging the client modelsâ€™ weights.

Here, we however study a different regularization effect, in personalized FL on local test sets. As reviewed inÂ subsectionÂ 3.1, personalized FL algorithms often impose a regularizer on the local/personalized models to overcome the fact that clients usually have limited data (please seeÂ EquationÂ 3 andÂ EquationÂ 4 and the surrounding text). What we claim is that even without such an explicit regularizer, the model weight average before local training (EquationÂ 2) already serves as an implicit regularizer to the local models for their individual personalized performance, as we discussed inÂ subsectionÂ 3.3 (FigureÂ 3) and empirically verified inÂ subsectionÂ D.2 andÂ FigureÂ 7.

A.5 Systematic overhead

Fed-RoD has similar computation cost, communication size, and number of parameters as FedAvg. We discuss the difference between Fed-RoD and existing generic FL methods from a system view. FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a) proposes a proximal term to prevent client from diverging from the server model, which is more robust to the heterogeneous system. SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b) imposes a gradient correction during client training. Maintaining such a correction term, however, doubles the size of communication. FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021) resolves the communication cost issue by introducing a novel dynamic regularization. However, it requires all users to maintain their previous models locally throughout the FL process, which is not desired when users have memory and synchronization constraints.

A.6 Class-imbalanced learning

Class-imbalanced learning attracts increasing attention for two reasons. First, models trained under this scenario using empirical risk minimization perform poorly on minor classes of scarce training data. Second, many real-world data sets are class-imbalanced by nature (VanÂ Horn etÂ al., 2018, Gupta etÂ al., 2019, VanÂ Horn & Perona, 2017). In this paper, we employ a mainstream approach, cost-sensitive learning (Ye etÂ al., 2020, Cao etÂ al., 2019, Ren etÂ al., 2020, Li etÂ al., 2020c, Tan etÂ al., 2020), which adjusts the training objective to reflect class imbalance so as to train a model that is less biased toward major classes.

A.7 Zero-shot learning

Our design choice of parameterizing the personalized prediction head with clientsâ€™ class distributions is reminiscent of zero-shot learning (Changpinyo etÂ al., 2016; 2020, Xian etÂ al., 2018, Changpinyo etÂ al., 2017, Lampert etÂ al., 2013), whose goal is to build an object classifier based on its semantic representation. The key difference is that we build an entire fully-connected layer for FL, not just a single class vector. We employ hypernetworks (Ha etÂ al., 2017) for efficient parameterization.

B.1 Additional background (cf. subsectionÂ 3.1 of the main paper)

In the generic federated learning (FL) setting, the goal is to construct a single â€œglobalâ€ model that can perform well for test data from all the clients. Let ğ’˜ğ’˜\bm{w} denote the parameters of the model, for a classification problem whose label space is â„‚â„‚\mathbb{C}, a commonly used loss is the cross entropy,

We note that, the concepts of global vs. local models and generic vs. personalized models should not be confused. No matter which task (generic or personalized) an FL algorithm focuses on, as long as it has the local training step, it generates local models; as long as it has the global aggregation step (of the entire model), it generates a global model. For instance, FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) aims for generic FL but it creates both the global and local models.

B.3 Balanced risk minimization (BRM)

To learn a generic model, standard federated learning (e.g., FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017)) aims to optimize â„’â€‹(ğ’˜)â„’ğ’˜\mathcal{L}(\bm{w}) in EquationÂ 1 of the main paper. In theory, the overall objective â„’â€‹(ğ’˜)â„’ğ’˜\mathcal{L}(\bm{w}) is equal to the expected objective ğ”¼â€‹[â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w})] for client mğ‘šm, if client mğ‘šmâ€™s data ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m} are IID partitioned from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}. Here, the expectation is over different ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m} partitioned from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}. In reality, â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m} could diverge from â„’â„’\mathcal{L} due to non-IID partitions of the aggregated data ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} into clientsâ€™ data. That is, ğ”¼â€‹[â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)]â‰ ğ”¼â€‹[â„’mâ€²â€‹(ğ’˜)]â‰ â„’â€‹(ğ’˜)ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptâ„’superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ’˜â„’ğ’˜\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w})]\neq\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}_{m^{\prime}}(\bm{w})]\neq\mathcal{L}(\bm{w}). We mitigate the non-IID situation by directly adjusting â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m} such that ğ”¼â€‹[â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)]â‰ˆğ”¼â€‹[â„’mâ€²â€‹(ğ’˜)]â‰ˆâ„’â€‹(ğ’˜)ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptâ„’superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ’˜â„’ğ’˜\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w})]\approx\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}_{m^{\prime}}(\bm{w})]\approx\mathcal{L}(\bm{w}).

Essentially, â„’mâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ’˜\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{w}) is the clientâ€™s empirical risk, which could be different among clients if their class distribution ğ’«mâ€‹(y)subscriptğ’«ğ‘šğ‘¦\mathcal{P}_{m}(y) are different. We, therefore, propose to turn the empirical risk â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m} into a class-balanced risk â„’mBâ€‹Rsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğµğ‘…\mathcal{L}_{m}^{{\color[rgb]{1,0,0}BR}} by replacing â„“â„“\ell in EquationÂ 12 with a class-balanced loss (Ren etÂ al., 2020, Cao etÂ al., 2019, Cui etÂ al., 2019, Ye etÂ al., 2020, Khan etÂ al., 2017, Kang etÂ al., 2020). The class-balanced loss attempts to make the learned model robust to different training class distributions, such that the learned model can perform well for all the test classes. In other words, the class-balanced loss is designed with an implicit assumption that the test data will be class-balanced, even though the training data may not be. TableÂ 5 summarizes some popular class-balanced losses. We also include some extensions with meta-learning. SeeÂ subsectionÂ B.5.

One may wonder what if the global distribution is class-imbalanced? Will BRM still be beneficial to FL? InÂ subsectionÂ D.5, we perform experiments to show that Fed-RoD with BRM can still improve on FedAvg since BRM seeks to learn every class well. Even though the global distribution might be skewed, BRM provides a novel alternative to mitigate the non-IID problem by making every client optimize a more consistent objective as we discussed above. Designing better losses for BRM in FL will be interesting future work.

B.4 On federated learning for the personalized head with hypernetworks

One drawback of existing personalized methods is that the personalized models are only available for clients involved in training or with sufficient training data. When new clients arrive in testing, is it possible for the federated system to provide corresponding personalized models?

To this end, instead of learning a specific prediction head Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} for each client mğ‘šm, we propose to learn a meta-model HPâ€‹(ğ’‚m;ğ‚)superscriptğ»ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ’‚ğ‘šğ‚H^{P}(\bm{a}_{m};\bm{\nu}) with a shared meta-parameter ğ‚ğ‚\bm{\nu}. The input to HPsuperscriptğ»ğ‘ƒH^{P} is a vector ğ’‚mâˆˆâ„|â„‚|subscriptğ’‚ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„â„‚\bm{a}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathbb{C}|}, which records the proportion of class câˆˆâ„‚ğ‘â„‚c\in\mathbb{C} in client mğ‘šmâ€™s data. The output of HPsuperscriptğ»ğ‘ƒH^{P} is Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} for hPsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ƒh^{P}. In other words, HPsuperscriptğ»ğ‘ƒH^{P} can adaptively output personalized prediction heads for clients given their local class distributions ğ’‚msubscriptğ’‚ğ‘š\bm{a}_{m}.

We implement the meta-model HPsuperscriptğ»ğ‘ƒH^{P} by a hypernetwork (Ha etÂ al., 2017), which can be seen as a lightweight classifier generator given ğ’‚msubscriptğ’‚ğ‘š\bm{a}_{m}. This lightweight hypernetwork not only enables clients to collaboratively learn a module that can generate customized models, but also allows any (future) clients to immediately generate their own personalized predictors given their local class distribution ğ’‚msubscriptğ’‚ğ‘š\bm{a}_{m} as input, even without training. We construct the hypernetwork by two fully-connected (FC) layers (with a ReLU nonlinear layer in between). TableÂ 6 summarizes the number of parameters of each part in Fed-RoD. Hypernetworks add only a small overhead to the original model.

B.5 Extension with meta-learning for the improved BSM loss

With a very small meta set, Fed-RoD outperforms (Zhao etÂ al., 2018) by 1%percent11\% to 14%percent1414\% on accuracy across different settings, validating the importance of balanced losses and how to set them up dynamically via meta-learning.

B.6 Connection to Invariant Risk Minimization Games (IRMG)

Fed-RoD is inspired by a recently proposed machine learning framework Invariant Risk Minimization (IRM)Â (Arjovsky etÂ al., 2019) and its extension Invariant Risk Minimization Games (IRMG)Â (Ahuja etÂ al., 2020).

Suppose that the whole dataset is collected from many environments, where data from each environment is associated with its characteristic, IRM introduces the concept of learning an invariant predictor. (Note that, in IRM the learner can access data from all the environments; thus, it is not for an FL setting.) Given the training data partition, IRM aims to learn an invariant feature extractor ğ’›=fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğœ½)ğ’›ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½{\bm{z}}=f({\bm{x}};\bm{\theta}) and a classifier hâ€‹(ğ’›;ğ)â„ğ’›ğh({\bm{z}};\bm{\psi}) that achieves the minimum risk for all the environments.

The concept of environments can be connected to clientsâ€™ private local data in FL which are often non-IID. That is, given Mğ‘€M environments, we can re-write IRM in a similar expression to EquationÂ 7 in the main paper

minğœ½,ğâ¡â„’IRMâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ)=âˆ‘m=1Mâ„’mâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ),subscriptğœ½ğsuperscriptâ„’IRMğœ½ğsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğœ½ğ\displaystyle\min_{\bm{\theta},\bm{\psi}}~{}\mathcal{L}^{\text{IRM}}(\bm{\theta},\bm{\psi})=\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{\theta},\bm{\psi}), (15)
s.tğâˆˆargâ€‹minğâ€²â¡â„’mâ€‹(ğœ½,ğâ€²),âˆ€mâˆˆ[M].formulae-sequences.tğsubscriptargminsuperscriptğâ€²subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğœ½superscriptğâ€²for-allğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘€\displaystyle\text{s.t}\quad\bm{\psi}\in\operatorname{arg\,min}_{\bm{\psi}^{\prime}}\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{\theta},\bm{\psi}^{\prime}),\forall m\in[M]. (16)

Unfortunately, IRM is intractable to solve in practice given the constraint that every environment relies on the same parametersÂ (Ahuja etÂ al., 2020). IRMG relaxes it by reformulating the classifier ğğ\bm{\psi} as an ensemble of environment-specific classifiers (by averaging over model weights) Ï•Â¯=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘mÏ•mÂ¯bold-italic-Ï•1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘šsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bar{\bm{\phi}}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m}\bm{\phi}_{m}:

minğœ½,Ï•Â¯â¡â„’IRMGâ€‹(ğœ½,Ï•Â¯)=âˆ‘m=1Mâ„’mâ€‹(ğœ½,Ï•Â¯),subscriptğœ½Â¯bold-italic-Ï•superscriptâ„’IRMGğœ½Â¯bold-italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€subscriptâ„’ğ‘šğœ½Â¯bold-italic-Ï•\displaystyle\min_{\bm{\theta},\bar{\bm{\phi}}}~{}\mathcal{L}^{\text{IRMG}}(\bm{\theta},\bar{\bm{\phi}})=\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{\theta},\bar{\bm{\phi}}), (17)
s.tÏ•mâˆˆargâ€‹minÏ•mâ€²=mâ¡â„’mâ€‹(ğœ½,{Ï•mâ€²}mâ€²=1M),âˆ€mâˆˆ[M].formulae-sequences.tsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘šsubscriptargminsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘šsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğœ½superscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²1ğ‘€for-allğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘€\displaystyle\text{s.t}\quad\bm{\phi}_{m}\in\operatorname{arg\,min}_{\bm{\phi}_{m^{\prime}=m}}\mathcal{L}_{m}(\bm{\theta},\{\bm{\phi}_{m^{\prime}}\}_{m^{\prime}=1}^{M}),\forall m\in[M]. (18)

IRMG is proved to optimize the same invariant predictor of IRM when it converges to the equilibrium in game theory, and it holds for a large class of non-linear classifiers. IRMG is solved through iterative optimization: (1) training the feature extractor ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} with centralized data (i.e., aggregated data from all environments), (2) training the environment-specific classifiers Ï•msubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bm{\phi}_{m} on the data of each environment ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m}, and (3) updating the main classifier through weight averaging Ï•Â¯=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘mÏ•mÂ¯bold-italic-Ï•1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘šsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\bar{\bm{\phi}}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m}\bm{\phi}_{m}.

We highlight the similarity between IRMG and Fed-RoD: both are training a strong generic feature extractor and a set of personalized classifiers. For predictions on data of client (environment) mğ‘šm inÂ EquationÂ 18, IRMG uses y^=1Mâ€‹(Ï•mâŠ¤â€‹ğ’›+âˆ‘mâ€²â‰ mÏ•mâ€²âŠ¤â€‹ğ’›)^ğ‘¦1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘štopğ’›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘šâ€²topğ’›\hat{y}=\frac{1}{M}(\phi_{m}^{\top}{\bm{z}}+\sum_{m^{\prime}\neq m}\bm{\phi}_{m^{\prime}}^{\top}{\bm{z}}); Fed-RoDâ€™s personalized model is y^=hGâ€‹(ğ’›;ğ)+hPâ€‹(ğ’›;Ï•m)^ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğºğ’›ğsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ƒğ’›subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š\hat{y}=h^{G}({\bm{z}};\bm{\psi})+h^{P}({\bm{z}};\bm{\phi}_{m}). We can connect IRMG to Fed-RoD by re-writing its prediction as hGâ€‹(ğ’›;Ï•Â¯):=Ï•Â¯âŠ¤â€‹ğ’›=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘mÏ•â€²mâŠ¤â€‹ğ’›assignsuperscriptâ„ğºğ’›Â¯bold-italic-Ï•superscriptÂ¯bold-italic-Ï•topğ’›1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-Ï•â€²ğ‘štopğ’›h^{G}({\bm{z}};\bar{\bm{\phi}}):=\bar{\bm{\phi}}^{\top}{\bm{z}}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m}{\bm{\phi}^{\prime}}_{m}^{\top}{\bm{z}} and hPâ€‹(ğ’›;Ï•m):=1Mâ€‹(Ï•mâŠ¤â€‹ğ’›âˆ’Ï•mâ€²âŠ¤â€‹ğ’›)assignsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ƒğ’›subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘š1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘štopğ’›superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-Ï•â€²ğ‘štopğ’›h^{P}({\bm{z}};\bm{\phi}_{m}):=\frac{1}{M}(\bm{\phi}_{m}^{\top}{\bm{z}}-{\bm{\phi}^{\prime}_{m}}^{\top}{\bm{z}}), where Ï•mâ€²subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-Ï•â€²ğ‘š{\bm{\phi}^{\prime}_{m}} is the client mğ‘šmâ€™s model in the previous round/iteration of learning.

IRMG can not be applied directly to federated learning for the following reasons. First, centralized training of the feature extractor is intractable since clientsâ€™ data are not allowed to be aggregated to the server. Second, to perform the iterative optimization of IRMG, the clients are required to communicate every step, which is not feasible in FL due to communication constraints.

Appendix C Implementation Details

Implementation.

We adopt ConvNetÂ (LeCun etÂ al., 1998) following the existing works (McMahan etÂ al., 2017, Acar etÂ al., 2021, TensorFlow team, 2016). For EMNIST/FMNIST, it contains 222 Conv layers and 222 FC layers. The Conv layers have 323232 and 646464 channels, respectively. The FC layers are with 505050 neurons as the hidden size and 101010 neurons for 101010 classes as outputs, respectively. For CIFAR-10/100, it contains 333 Conv layers and 222 FC layers. The Conv layers have 323232, 646464, and 646464 channels, respectively. The FC layers are with 646464 neurons as the hidden size and 10/1001010010/100 neurons for 10/1001010010/100 classes as outputs, respectively. To implement hypernetworks in Fed-RoD, we use a simple 2-FC ReLU network with hidden size 161616 for EMNIST/FMNIST/CIFAR-100 and 323232 for CIFAR-10.

We use standard pre-processing, where EMNIST/FMNIST and CIFAR-10/100 images are normalized. EMNIST/FMNIST is trained without augmentation. The 32Ã—32323232\times 32 CIFAR-10/100 images are padded 222 pixels each side, randomly flipped horizontally, and then randomly cropped back to 32Ã—32323232\times 32.

We train every method for 100100100 rounds. We initialize the model weights from normal distributions. As mentioned in (Li etÂ al., 2020b), the local learning rate must decay along the communication rounds. We initialize it with 0.010.010.01 and decay it by 0.990.990.99 every round, similar toÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021). Throughout the experiments, we use the SGD optimizer with weight decay 1â€‹eâˆ’51e51\mathrm{e}{-5} and a 0.90.90.9 momentum. The mini-batch size is 404040 (161616 for EMNIST). In each round, clients perform local training for 555 epochs. We report the mean over five times of experiments with different random seeds.

For FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a), the strength of regularization Î»ğœ†\lambda is selected from [1â€‹eâˆ’2,1â€‹eâˆ’3,1â€‹eâˆ’4]1e21e31e4[\mathrm{1e}{-2},\mathrm{1e}{-3},\mathrm{1e}{-4}]. For FedDyn (Acar etÂ al., 2021), the strength of regularization Î»ğœ†\lambda is selected from [1â€‹eâˆ’1,1â€‹eâˆ’2,1â€‹eâˆ’3]1e11e21e3[\mathrm{1e}{-1},\mathrm{1e}{-2},\mathrm{1e}{-3}] as suggested in (Acar etÂ al., 2021). For Per-FedAvgÂ (Fallah etÂ al., 2020), the meta-learning rate Î²^^ğ›½\hat{\beta} is selected from [1â€‹eâˆ’2,1â€‹eâˆ’3,1â€‹eâˆ’4]1e21e31e4[\mathrm{1e}{-2},\mathrm{1e}{-3},\mathrm{1e}{-4}]. For pFedMeÂ (Dinh etÂ al., 2020), the strength of regularization Î»ğœ†\lambda is selected from [15,20,30]152030[15,20,30]. Fed-RoD introduces no extra hyperparameters on top of FedAvg.

For the generic and personalized heads of Fed-RoD, we study using 1âˆ¼4similar-to141\sim 4 FC layers but do not see a notable gain by using more layers. We attribute this to the well-learned generic features. Thus, for all our experiments on Fed-RoD, we use a single FC layer for each head.

We run our experiments on four GeForce RTX 2080 Ti GPUs with Intel i9-9960X CPUs.

Evaluation.

Both datasets and the non-IID Dirichlet simulation are widely studied and used in literatureÂ (Hsu etÂ al., 2019, Lin etÂ al., 2020, Acar etÂ al., 2021). We use the standard balanced test set ğ’Ÿtestsubscriptğ’Ÿtest\mathcal{D}_{\text{test}} for evaluation on generic FL (G-FL):

G-FLâ€‹accuracy:1|ğ’Ÿtest|â€‹âˆ‘i1â€‹(yi=y^i,G),:G-FLaccuracy1subscriptğ’Ÿtestsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–ğº\displaystyle\textbf{G-FL}\hskip 4.0pt\text{accuracy}:\hskip 4.0pt\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{\text{test}}|}\sum_{i}\textbf{1}(y_{i}=\hat{y}_{i,G}), (19)

where y^i,Gsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–ğº\hat{y}_{i,G} here is the predicted label (i.e., argâ€‹maxargmax\operatorname{arg\,max} over the logits). For evaluation on personalized FL (P-FL), we still apply ğ’Ÿtestsubscriptğ’Ÿtest\mathcal{D}_{\text{test}} but weight instances w.r.t. each clientâ€™s class distribution:

P-FLâ€‹accuracy:1Mâ€‹âˆ‘mâˆ‘iğ’«mâ€‹(yi)â€‹1â€‹(yi=y^i,P)âˆ‘iğ’«mâ€‹(yi).:P-FLaccuracy1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’«ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’«ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\displaystyle\textbf{P-FL}\hskip 4.0pt\text{accuracy}:\hskip 4.0pt\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m}\frac{\sum_{i}\mathcal{P}_{m}(y_{i})\textbf{1}(y_{i}=\hat{y}_{i,P})}{\sum_{i}\mathcal{P}_{m}(y_{i})}. (20)

We do so instead of separating ğ’Ÿtestsubscriptğ’Ÿtest\mathcal{D}_{\text{test}} into separate clientsâ€™ test sets in order to avoid the variance caused by how we split test data (except the EMNIST dataset that each client has its own test set with the writerâ€™s styles). What we compute is essentially the expectation over the splits. We have verified that the difference of the two evaluation methods is negligible.

In TableÂ 1 of the main paper and some other tables in the appendix, we evaluate G-FL by an FL algorithmâ€™s generic (usually the global) model, denoted as GM. We evaluate P-FL by an FL algorithmâ€™s personalized models (or local models of a G-FL algorithm), denoted as PM. For P-FL, we also report the generic modelâ€™s accuracy following the literature to demonstrate the difference.

Due to the space limit of the main paper, we provide the standard deviations of the results of TableÂ 1 in TableÂ 7, TableÂ 8, and TableÂ 9 here.
